title: GOP preps for battle after Election Day
content:
Operatives are gaming out the runoff scenario in Louisiana and Georgia . | AP Photos GOP preps for post-Election Day fight
Republicans are hoarding money in a key race that could determine control of the Senate , leaving themselves vulnerable to being outgunned by Democrats ahead of Election Day .
Top Republican strategists are quietly preparing to pour money into Louisiana after November , even reserving hotel rooms and millions of dollars ’ worth of ad time . If Democratic Sen. Mary Landrieu doesn ’ t win more than half the vote in the general election , she would very likely be forced into a one-on-one runoff with Republican Rep. Bill Cassidy .
The situation is similar in neighboring Georgia , where campaigns for both parties are prepared to ratchet up turnout if the race goes to a nine-week runoff ending in January .
Republicans had hoped to take back the Senate in a show of force this year , but the strategic preparations in two key states suggest the party is preparing for a prolonged fight — that could even go into next year — and end in a photo finish .
“ It ’ s a very intense period of time , ” said Sen. Johnny Isakson , a Georgia Republican who battled in his own runoff race in 1996 when he competed for voters ’ attention during the Olympic Games in Atlanta . “ You ’ ve got to recapitalize almost immediately , and it ’ s a matter of who gets their voters out to the polls . ”
The specter of runoffs in key states is forcing the parties to make a critical choice : Spend precious resources now or conserve some until a winter campaign that may not happen .
Operatives are gaming out the runoff scenario — particularly in Louisiana where planning includes sending in lawyers and figuring out how they ’ ll sustain the party ’ s get-out-the-vote efforts .
In Georgia , both sides have built an infrastructure they are planning to rely on if it goes to a runoff and are already predicting a major fundraising blitz if the winner isn ’ t decided on election night .
Republicans have made concrete plans with the National Republican Senatorial Committee already reserving $ 3.4 million in TV time for the Louisiana runoff , while the conservative outside group Freedom Partners has booked an additional $ 1.5 million for a potential post-Election Day affair , according to sources familiar with the matter . Karl Rove-backed Crossroads GPS has $ 2.1 million reserved in the state starting Oct. 7 .
“ Whether the outcome is decided in November or December , we are committed to defeating Mary Landrieu , ” said Crossroads spokesman Paul Lindsay .
Americans for Prosperity , which has about two dozen staffers in the state , is focusing on the ground game and would add additional staff if a runoff occurs , according to a source familiar with their efforts .
Democrats have yet to reserve airtime in Louisiana , and both sides are staying off the air for the runoff in Georgia — for now .
In Louisiana , Democrats believe their best shot at emerging victorious in the race is to win outright in November , taking advantage of a split between Cassidy and his main conservative foe , tea party challenger Rob Maness .
“ The only pathway Republicans have to victory is through a runoff . We have a pathway to victory without a runoff that ’ s just it , ” said Louisiana Democratic Party Executive Director Stephen Handwerk .
The runoff — which would presumably unite Republicans behind one candidate — becomes a much more dangerous proposition for Landrieu and her party .
That ’ s why Democrats don ’ t want to let on that they are planning a furious post-election fight , even though they are quietly plotting an aggressive ground and aerial attack to keep the seat in their hands if a runoff occurs .
“ I ’ m just running a hard race no matter who is in the race against me , and I feel pretty confident — whether it ’ s one or two or three [ opponents ] — that I can get 50 percent in the first [ election ] and win , ” Landrieu said .
The Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee is also mum on what its runoff plans entail .
“ We aren ’ t getting into plans for either runoff right now ; we ’ re focused on winning both races on Election Day , ” said DSCC spokesman Justin Barasky .
Assuming he faces Landrieu in a runoff , Cassidy , her main opponent , said he already has a plan to consolidate GOP support behind his candidacy : Focus on Barack Obama .
” As long as we keep on opposing the president 97 percent of the time , where she supports him 97 percent of the time , ” Cassidy said , he ’ d end up winning over Maness ’ supporters .

But it could be worth it.

The situation is similar in neighboring Georgia, where campaigns for both parties are prepared to ratchet up turnout if the race goes to a nine-week runoff ending in January.

Johnny Isakson, a Georgia Republican who battled in his own runoff race in 1996 when he competed for voters’ attention during the Olympic Games in Atlanta. “You’ve got to recapitalize almost immediately, and it’s a matter of who gets their voters out to the polls.”

The specter of runoffs in key states is forcing the parties to make a critical choice: Spend precious resources now or conserve some until a winter campaign that may not happen.

Operatives are gaming out the runoff scenario — particularly in Louisiana where planning includes sending in lawyers and figuring out how they’ll sustain the party’s get-out-the-vote efforts.

In Georgia, both sides have built an infrastructure they are planning to rely on if it goes to a runoff and are already predicting a major fundraising blitz if the winner isn’t decided on election night.

Republicans have made concrete plans with the National Republican Senatorial Committee already reserving $3.4 million in TV time for the Louisiana runoff, while the conservative outside group Freedom Partners has booked an additional $1.5 million for a potential post-Election Day affair, according to sources familiar with the matter. Karl Rove-backed Crossroads GPS has $2.1 million reserved in the state starting Oct. 7.

“Whether the outcome is decided in November or December, we are committed to defeating Mary Landrieu,” said Crossroads spokesman Paul Lindsay.

Americans for Prosperity, which has about two dozen staffers in the state, is focusing on the ground game and would add additional staff if a runoff occurs, according to a source familiar with their efforts.

In Louisiana, Democrats believe their best shot at emerging victorious in the race is to win outright in November, taking advantage of a split between Cassidy and his main conservative foe, tea party challenger Rob Maness.

“The only pathway Republicans have to victory is through a runoff. We have a pathway to victory without a runoff that’s just it,” said Louisiana Democratic Party Executive Director Stephen Handwerk.

The runoff — which would presumably unite Republicans behind one candidate — becomes a much more dangerous proposition for Landrieu and her party.

That’s why Democrats don’t want to let on that they are planning a furious post-election fight, even though they are quietly plotting an aggressive ground and aerial attack to keep the seat in their hands if a runoff occurs.

“I’m just running a hard race no matter who is in the race against me, and I feel pretty confident — whether it’s one or two or three [opponents] — that I can get 50 percent in the first [election] and win,” Landrieu said.

Assuming he faces Landrieu in a runoff, Cassidy, her main opponent, said he already has a plan to consolidate GOP support behind his candidacy: Focus on Barack Obama.

”As long as we keep on opposing the president 97 percent of the time, where she supports him 97 percent of the time,” Cassidy said, he’d end up winning over Maness’ supporters.
